text:
That’d be awesome. I had done research and worked on a proposal for a blog that would serve both sides of the marketplace at Eventbrite. But I had a lot more useful analytics from the separate B2C and B2B blogs to show how they could be feasibility combined. 

I’m now working on a similar problem at Udemy but we don’t have nearly as much data and I’m still building our engine from bits and pieces that existed. My experience and intuition are telling me how to go about it but It’s helpful to have some data to make sure I’m not being overconfident.

elements.text:

text:
I'm generally looking for industry/experience in the areas that need writing, I find them via LinkedIn & Twitter, and/or writing communities, and the biggest no-no is typos on their website. Not being able to sell yourself is one thing (we've all been there!), but poor grasp of basic English and lack of attention to detail is something that you can't overcome

I'd be interested to see the findings of this report, btw :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
Does anyone here have a role at their content marketing company that is primarily the marketing/distribution person? If so, how do you track their activity/deliverables?

I’m basically that person now and we are trying to figure out my “outputs” per month but it’s tough because (for example) securing organic placement in an industry pub is something that I can secure one month and not see the publication for another month or two. Any thoughts on this?

elements.text: Does anyone here have a role at their content marketing company that is primarily the marketing/distribution person? If so, how do you track their activity/deliverables?

text:
this may have been asked already but…
*Agency vs in house vs ___* (Am I missing one?)

Which role is best for different stages of your career (Junior, senior, etc.)?

elements.text: this may have been asked already but…
Agency vs in house vs ___

(Am I missing one?)

Which role is best for different stages of your career (Junior, senior, etc.)?

text: freelance!

elements.text: freelance!

text: Tell me more! :writing_hand: :brain: [me taking mental notes]

elements.text: Tell me more!
[me taking mental notes]

text: Typically I'd recommend getting some agency or in-house experience first, so that you can learn how things are done in a more structured environment. But freelance work is a great way to boost your income, build  a business, get more freedom, etc. at a mid to senior point in your career (IMO)

elements.text: Typically I'd recommend getting some agency or in-house experience first, so that you can learn how things are done in a more structured environment. But freelance work is a great way to boost your income, build  a business, get more freedom, etc. at a mid to senior point in your career (IMO)

text: [Is that what you're interested in?]

elements.text: [Is that what you're interested in?]

text: Yes thank you! I had the thought that freelancing was great for those early in their career but you’re saying it’s better for those with more experience?

elements.text: Yes thank you! I had the thought that freelancing was great for those early in their career but you’re saying it’s better for those with more experience?

text: I don't think it's black and white, but getting some agency or in-house structured experience will help you figure out what you're doing before you start taking on clients

elements.text: I don't think it's black and white, but getting some agency or in-house structured experience will help you figure out what you're doing before you start taking on clients

text: (I found that to be the case for me)

elements.text: (I found that to be the case for me)

text: Certainly you can freelance early in your career, but it can be hard to know where to focus or how to be successful at it without some type of model

elements.text: Certainly you can freelance early in your career, but it can be hard to know where to focus or how to be successful at it without some type of model

text: (Freelance writing I think is a bit simpler in some ways, but freelance content marketing requires some experience and knowledge)

elements.text: (Freelance writing I think is a bit simpler in some ways, but freelance content marketing requires some experience and knowledge)

text: There's obviously overlap :wink:

elements.text: There's obviously overlap

text: This is very true! Thank you (I’m trying to figure my future career out and that gave me some context!)

elements.text: This is very true! Thank you (I’m trying to figure my future career out and that gave me some context!)

text: I'm a big believer in the value of agency for early career folks, in particular. You get exposure to a wide variety of companies and industries, all approaching content in different ways. Accelerates the learning curve and allows you to build your toolkit of strategies and tactics so you have more to pull from when you go in-house.

elements.text: I'm a big believer in the value of agency for early career folks, in particular. You get exposure to a wide variety of companies and industries, all approaching content in different ways. Accelerates the learning curve and allows you to build your toolkit of strategies and tactics so you have more to pull from when you go in-house.

text: Plus another bonus: you can get exposure to the biz side and get visibility into rates, sales processes, etc. which can all be really really valuable if/when you do decide to set up shop for yourself freelance

elements.text: Plus another bonus: you can get exposure to the biz side and get visibility into rates, sales processes, etc. which can all be really really valuable if/when you do decide to set up shop for yourself freelance

text: Having bounced between the two I personally get really excited about being able to focus on one thing being in-house ... then after a few years I get a little burnt out and decide I’d prefer the challenge of working on lots of different industries at once. You may find yourself in a place where one or the other just feels right, and you’ll probably do the best in that environment.

elements.text: Having bounced between the two I personally get really excited about being able to focus on one thing being in-house ... then after a few years I get a little burnt out and decide I’d prefer the challenge of working on lots of different industries at once. You may find yourself in a place where one or the other just feels right, and you’ll probably do the best in that environment.

text: The Content Strategy Podcast with Kristina Halvorson was really good but they haven't published new ones in a long time. The Content Rookie is another good one for writing (pretty broad scope), and Copy Pros can be fun.
